description: Dive into "Architectural Wonders of Ahmedabad Awaits" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Architectural Wonders of Ahmedabad Awaits

places.generalDescription: Adalaj Stepwell, also known as Adalaj ni Vav, is a historical stepwell located in the village of Adalaj near Ahmedabad city in Gujarat. Dating back to 1499, this architectural marvel was commissioned by Queen Rudabai in memory of her husband. The stepwell features intricate carvings on its walls and is a popular heritage site in Gujarat.

sources.snippet: Squeeze in time for another sub-terrain stepwell‚Äìyou won‚Äôt want to miss the beauty of the Adalaj Stepwell built in the late 1400s. These structures were once essential to life in the semi-arid regions of India since they provided a reliable source of water for daily activities. There is a legend surrounding this stepwell specifically, relating to the wife of a king that was killed by an invader.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer‚Äôs Guide to Architecture in Ahmedabad ‚Äì Passion Passport

sources.snippet: Construction year: 1499Architecture style: Solanki Architecture. The Adalaj Stepwell is an iconic stepped well showcasing India‚Äôs finest craftsmanship and architecture of the era. It is in the town of Adalaj which is situated on the outskirts of Ahmedabad city.
sources.shortName: Ahmedabad City Guide: 8 historical and modern architecture to visit

places.name: The Adalaj Stepwell

reviews.text:
Very unique art. The rock carvings here are special. This is essentially a water reservoir for people.

You should give more time to understand the rock carvings.

I will go back and see if an expert like @RealPraveenMohan had any video on this place. üåü

This is very good and highly recommended for all those who love to see historical places or Bhartiya heritage.

‡ÆÜ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç.

Do Not Travel to Gujarat from March to July, the heat is very very very High.

Adalaj stepwell is also called Rudabhai Step well, named after the queen, in whose honor it was built. Felt so happy we could visit this place and admire the beauty of it.

Stepwells are basically wells for washing, drinking and bathing purely for the ladies and it is very common in Gujarat and rajasthan area. The earliest step wells date back to 2nd century AD.

Over time, these step wells became an architectural marvel and wonderful place to show case their talent, their intricate carvings, their stunning symmetry. It is a wonderful place not only  for history lovers but for photographers too.

The Rudabhai step well is a five storied step well, built in 1498 by the then king Rana veer singh but completed in record time by Mohammed Begda the muslim ruler who killed Rana veer singh in battle.

Legend says, the queen Rudabhai tricked mohammed begda to finish the step well in record time on the condition that she will marry him, but when the step well was completed, she went back on her promise and killed her self in this step well.

You can also see some tombs on the step well and the legend goes that the mohammed begda killed the people who constructed such a fantastic step well in record time.

Definitely a must visit place if you are visiting Gujarat and in particular Ahmedabad. The place is more beautiful when you see it with your own eyes than in the photographs that you see on the net.

I like places that have historical significance, it shows where we are heading as a society. Everything around here is well maintained from the lush green parks to the maintenance of the stepwell. The smell of bats is one issue but again that's what makes this place authentic.

places.address: Adalaj Rd, Adalaj, Gujarat 382421, India

places.generalDescription: Trimandir, Adalaj is a non-sectarian temple complex located near the Adalaj Stepwell. It opens at dawn and offers a picturesque setting for photography enthusiasts. The temple reflects the concept of three different religions - Jainism, Shaivism, and Vaishnavism - while also worshipping other deities. The Gigantic Hall is particularly recommended for capturing stunning pictures.

sources.snippet: Near the Adalaj Stepwell is the Trimandir-Adalaj Temple: the headquarters of Dada Bhagwan. The temple usually opens at dawn, so it might be worth it to wake up early in order to get the perfect shot. The temple was built in order to reflect the concept of three different religions including Jainism, Shaivism, and Vaishnavism, though other gods and goddesses are worshipped here too.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer‚Äôs Guide to Architecture in Ahmedabad ‚Äì Passion Passport

sources.snippet: This beautiful architectural masterpiece is a picture-perfect frame during the early morning hours. Trimandir Adalaj Temple was built to reflect the concept of three religions ‚Äì Jainism, Shaivism and Vaishnavism. If you‚Äôre a photography enthusiast or an Instagram star, the Gigantic Hall is the best place for pictures in this temple.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Historical Architectural Marvels of Ahmedabad

places.name: Trimandir, Adalaj

reviews.text:
Trimandir in Adalaj is a stunning spiritual retreat that beautifully blends modern architecture with traditional values. The temple is dedicated to the teachings of Param Pujya Dada Bhagwan and offers a serene atmosphere for meditation and reflection.

As you enter, the intricate carvings and vibrant colors immediately capture your attention, creating a peaceful ambiance that invites visitors to pause and contemplate. The main hall is spacious and beautifully adorned, making it an ideal place for prayer and spiritual gatherings.

The staff is welcoming and eager to share the teachings of Dada Bhagwan, providing insightful guidance for those seeking spiritual growth. The surrounding gardens are well-maintained and offer a tranquil space for leisurely walks.

Overall, Trimandir is not just a place of worship but a sanctuary for those looking to deepen their understanding of spirituality. Whether you are a local or a visitor, it's a must-visit destination that leaves you feeling rejuvenated and inspired. Highly recommended!

Its a serene and beautiful temple complex. The stunning architecture, tranquil atmosphere, and intricate carvings make it a must-visit. The temple's unique concept of worshiping multiple deities in one place was noticed.

Trimandir Gandhinagar is a calm and beautiful temple near Adalaj. It is special because it brings together Jain, Shiv, and Krishna beliefs in one place. The temple is very clean and nicely built with marble idols of different gods. There are gardens, fountains, and places to sit and relax. You can also visit a small museum, book shop, and enjoy food in the canteen. Rooms are available if you want to stay. It's a peaceful place to pray, meditate, or spend time with family. The positive and friendly atmosphere makes it a great place to visit for everyone.

places.address: Mehsana Highway, Simandhar City, Trimandir, Ahmedabad, Adalaj, Gujarat 382421, India

places.generalDescription: The Hutheesing Jain Temple, also known as Hatheesingh Jain Derasar, is a 19th-century marvel located in Madhupura locality of Ahmedabad, Gujarat. Constructed in 1850 by Seth Hutheesing, this grand Jain temple is dedicated to Lord Dharmnath, the 15th Jain Tirthankara.

sources.snippet: The temple is one of the most prestigious Jain temples in Ahmedabad, dedicated to the 15th Tirthankara ‚Äì Lord Dharmanath. It was constructed in 1848 by the Hutheesing family, and it blends the traditional Marwadi-Gujarati architectural styles with new design elements in the Haveli. The temple is a sight to behold during the festive season with the mesmerising lights.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Historical Architectural Marvels of Ahmedabad

sources.snippet: The impeccable white marble structure of the Hutheesing Jain Temple attracts photographers daily. The impressive structure is covered with elaborate carvings and is the most celebrated Jain temple in the city although it only dates back to the 1800s. Built by a wealthy trader and supervised by his wife, the cost was incredibly expensive at the time.
sources.shortName: An Instagrammer‚Äôs Guide to Architecture in Ahmedabad ‚Äì Passion Passport

sources.snippet: Hutheesing Jain Temple | #8 of 13 Historical Places in Ahmedabad. Hutheesing Jain Temple is one of the most prominent Jain shrines in Ahmedabad, dedicated to the 15 th Tirthankara, Lord Dharmanatha. An affluent trader from Ahmedabad named Shet Hathisinh Kesarisinh initiated the construction of this temple.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

sources.snippet: This is one of the most important Jain temples in the city and is dedicated to the 15 th Tirthankara of the Jains, Lord Dharmanath. The temple is two storeyed and is completed created in marble. The outer courtyard of the temple is truly splendid and you will have splendid grounds to walk on.
sources.shortName: 12 Magnificent Historical Places In Ahemdabad That You Must Visit

sources.snippet: Dedicated to the 15th Tirthankara of Jains, Dharmanath, this two-storied white marble structure provides a delightful experience and the tiled courtyard is another unique aspect of the temple.
sources.shortName: 16 Historical Places In Ahmedabad For Local Heritage and History

places.name: Hutheesing Jain Temple

reviews.text: Beautiful jain temple. Photography is not allowed inside but there are all the 42 gods of Jainism and the main statue is of gold. Architecture is beautiful üòç Do spend some time here

‡ÆÜ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç.

Do Not Travel to Gujarat from March to July, the heat is very very very High.

Dress code is applicable in this temple and definitely no cameras and photos of any sort once you cross the doors of the main temple.

Visited this Jain temple in the middle of Ahmedabad. We did go and pray and also enjoyed the way the temple was constructed so beautifully. The entrance to the temple was simply superb construction wise.

They say it was built in the 18th century, and the temple faces west.

We went in the early morning hence the sun was directly the mob camera making the photos totally dark. So probably the good time to get good photos one must visit in the evening time say after 5 pm.

Nicely carved Jain temple in the heart of Ahmedabad. As is usual in Jain temples, the ambience is calm and facilitates meditation and silence. Some construction is still going on, so some debris is there near the construction area. Well worth a visit for the visual beauty & the peaceful ambience.
Quite a large temple, photography is prohibited, which is always a downer for me.

places.address: 40, Shahibaug Rd., Bardolpura, Madhupura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380016, India

places.generalDescription: Sidi Saiyyed Mosque, constructed in 1573, is a stunning example of Islamic architecture located in Ahmedabad. The mosque is famous for its intricate latticework, particularly the delicate tree designs carved into its stone windows. This architectural gem showcases the influence of the African diaspora in India and features a mesmerizing sixteen-foot Sidi Saiyyed Jaali with the Tree of Life motif.

sources.snippet: Construction year: 1573Architecture style: Indo-Saracenic Architecture. The Sidi Sayed Mosque built by Sidi Sayed (Habshi nobleman) in 1573 is one of the most prominent mosques located in Ahmedabad. It is situated in the heart of Ahmedabad city and is one of the iconic mosque architectures recognized for its beautiful intricate stone latticework and ornamentation.
sources.shortName: Ahmedabad City Guide: 8 historical and modern architecture to visit

places.name: Sidi Saiyyed Masjid

reviews.text: Wonderful mosque situated in the heart of the city. I love this mosque. The carving net of trees and terracotta designs is fascinating. Feel divine and peaceful place.

‡ÆÜ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç   dt 22-03-25.

Do Not Travel to Gujarat from March to July, the heat is very very very High.

Visited this famous well known mosque. Ladies are not allowed inside the mosque.

Mosque is quiet small and compact, but highlights the beauty of the indo islamic architecture.

Built in the year 1572-73 by an Abyssinian (person from Ethiopia) called Sidi Saiyyed, who served under the then sultan. This mosque is well known for the wonderful intricate carvings in stone and their unique semi circular tracery windows, depicting the tree of life.

Paper cutouts were made of the carved screens from which two wooden replicas were made and these are now in museum in London and New york.

The driver was telling us that this mosque is still in use as the emblem of the Ahmedabad municipality.

The grave of sidi saiyyed is inside this mosque.

The mosque is in a congested area, hence parking is out of the question. Definitely worth a visit to admire the wonderful jalli work in the windows.

The Sidi Saiyyed Mosque, built by a prominent Habshi noble in 1572‚Äì73, is revered for its exquisite jali screens-especially the iconic Tree of Life motif-and is celebrated as one of the finest monuments of Indo-Islamic art in Ahmedabad. Its enduring legacy reflects both its architectural vibrancy and the cultural history of the city.

places.address: Bhadra Rd, Opposite Electricity House, Old City, Gheekanta, Lal Darwaja, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380001, India

places.generalDescription: Jama Masjid, a stunning yellow-sandstone mosque, was built in 1424 by Sultan Ahmed Shah I in Ahmedabad. It is not only the city's but also the country's most popular and beautiful mosque. The intriguing history of its construction and the materials used are interlinked with its stunning architecture. Adjacent to the mosque lies a mausoleum where Sultan Ahmed Shah I, his son, and grandson are buried.

sources.snippet: Standing during the reign of Sultan Ahmed Shah, Jama Masjid happens to be on the top of the checklist for the architects. Built during 1423, Jama Masjid marks the place for the Muslims of Ahmedabad to gather for Friday prayers. With fine carvings on 260 pillars and yellow sandstone, it resembles the grandeur of the Bhadra Fort.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ahmedabad for the Travelling Architect - RTF

sources.snippet: Construction year: 1424Architecture style: Indo-Islamic Architecture. Jama Masjid is an architectural masterpiece built during the reign of Sultan Ahmed Shah I in the year 1424. The mosque displays architecture that has been intricately designed and fused with Islamic, Hindu, and Jain architectural elements and influence.
sources.shortName: Ahmedabad City Guide: 8 historical and modern architecture to visit

sources.snippet: When Sultan Ahmed Shah built the colossal Jama Masjid in 1424, it was one of the largest mosques in India at the time. Located in the old walled city, this gorgeous mosque stands right outside Bhadra Fort. The mosque is built in yellow sandstone and is a fine example of the Indo-Saracenic style of architecture.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

places.name: Jama Masjid

reviews.text: Jama Masjid is a stunning architectural marvel and a must-visit historical landmark, the mosque showcases beautiful Indo-Islamic architecture, with intricately carved stone pillars, grand arches, and a vast courtyard that exudes serenity.

Jama Masjid in Ahmedabad is the best place. With the  perfect blend of history, culture, and tranquility. The moment you step into its huge premises.. you feel a sense of peace. Built in 1424 by Sultan Ahmed Shah, the mosque's intricate carvings, grand pillars, and stunning latticework tell stories of a rich past.

The architecture is mesmerizing, especially when the sunlight filters through the stone screens, casting beautiful patterns on the ground.

It's best to visit in the early morning or evening when the golden hues of the sandstone shine the brightest. Whether you're here for prayer, history, or simply to admire the beauty, Jama Masjid leaves a lasting impression.

A must-visit gem in the heart of Ahmedabad!

‡ÆÜ‡Æô‡Øç‡Æï‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Æ§‡Øç‡Æ§‡Æø‡Æ≤‡Øç ‡Æé‡Æ¥‡ØÅ‡Æ§‡ØÅ‡Æµ‡Æ§‡Æ±‡Øç‡Æï‡ØÅ ‡ÆÆ‡Æ©‡Øç‡Æ©‡Æø‡Æï‡Øç‡Æï‡Æµ‡ØÅ‡ÆÆ‡Øç   dt 22-03-25.

Do Not Travel to Gujarat from March to July, the heat is very very very High.

Ladies can enter the Masjid but are not allowed inside the prayer hall of the masjid.

Read about this Masjid in the internet, so it was very happy to see it in real. It is in the old city of Ahmedabad, and the driver told us, that it would be good to visit this Masjid before 10 am. After that the market opens and there will be heavy traffic.

Built by Ahmad shah in 1424 A.D, who is the founder of the city of Ahmedabad. The mosque is very beautiful to look at. As you stand at the small entrance from the road you can see how beautiful is the plan of the mosque.

There is the prayer hall, and then a large courtyard, which is covered on all 3 sides by corridors. As you go into the prayer hall you can notice the 15 wonderful high raise domes resting on 260 pillars. The buttress on either side of the main arch and as you enter the main arch the pillars are all beautifully carved.

They have put a green sheet to protect the people who come pray from the sun, but that sheet is definitely spoiling the beauty of the Masjid. They also say that this Masjid had lofty minarets similar to the jama masjid in Delhi but it collapsed in 1819.

we enjoyed the construction of the mosque and came out since we didn't want to be in the way of the people who were coming in to say their prayers.

places.address: 2HFP+GMC, Manek Chowk, Gandhi Rd, Danapidth, Khadia, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380001, India

places.generalDescription: Located 19 km from Ahmedabad Junction, the Shri Maa Vaishnodevi Temple is a significant Hindu pilgrimage site in Ahmedabad. Built in 2007, this temple is dedicated to Goddess Vaishnodevi and replicates the original temple in Jammu Kashmir. Situated on the Sarkhej - Gandhinagar highway, it features small caves and a man-made hill made of sandstone.

sources.shortName: 16 Historical Places In Ahmedabad For Local Heritage and History

places.name: Shri Maa Vaishnodevi Temple, Ahmedabad

reviews.text:
"Mata Vaishno Devi Temple on S.G. Highway, Ahmedabad, is a divine place that cannot be expressed in words. I have been visiting here for years, and every time, the experience is deeply spiritual. If you believe in Mata Rani Ji, this temple is a must-visit.

The temple is a replica of the sacred Mata Vaishno Devi shrine in Katra, offering a similar pilgrimage experience. The journey begins with Ardh Kuwari Cave, followed by Mata Rani Bhawan (the main temple), and concludes with the final darshan of Bhairo Baba. The serene atmosphere and divine energy make it a truly special place for devotees."**Jai Mata Di

A well-constructed temple in Ahmedabad that tries to simulate the tunnel through the rock pathway as in the temple at Katra.
Here one has to literally crawl through the tunnel in some places which is a humbling experience.
Just like in Katra, you are given a coin. Phones are allowed, but they must be switched off, else the security guard will do it for you!
There is one restaurant at the entrance within the complex where one can get hot freshly prepared snacks and two or three shops where packaged food and beverages are available.

Entry Fee:

There is no entry fee to visit the temple.

The Shri Maa Vaishnodevi Temple in Ahmedabad is a prominent Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Vaishnodevi, a manifestation of Goddess Durga.

Located on National Highway 147 (also known as Sarkhej-Gandhinagar Highway), it's a significant pilgrimage site in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

Here's a summary of its key features:

Replica Temple: It's a replica of the original Vaishno Devi Temple in Jammu and Kashmir, aiming to offer devotees a similar spiritual experience.

Architecture:
The temple is situated on an artificial hillock, simulating the mountain environment of the original shrine. This circular hill is built of yellow sandstone and features intricate carvings and sculptures of various gods and goddesses.

Layout:
Pilgrims journey through a man-made cave to reach the main shrine at the top of the hill, replicating the experience of visiting the original temple.

Significance:
It's a popular destination, particularly during the Navratri festival, attracting large numbers of devotees who seek the blessings of Goddess Vaishnodevi.

Accessibility:
The temple is situated approximately 19 km from Ahmedabad Junction and is well-connected by road, rail, and air. The nearest bus stop is at Vaishanavdevi Circle.

Timings:
The temple is generally open for darshan from 5:00 AM to 10:00 PM. However, it's worth noting that one source states the temple is only open until 7 PM and that there are restricted entry times during Aarti (6:00 PM to 6:45 PM).

Dress Code:
While not strictly enforced, it's advisable to wear modest attire that covers the upper arms and legs as a mark of respect.

places.address: 4GQV+4F7, NH147, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 382501, India

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the vibrant city of Ahmedabad, the Indian Institute of Management‚ÄìAhmedabad (IIM‚ÄìAhmedabad) stands as a beacon of excellence in business education. Established in 1961 and designed by the illustrious architect Louis Kahn, this institution beautifully marries modern architectural principles with traditional Indian aesthetics. The campus spans an impressive 60 acres, featuring minimalist buildings set amidst lush gardens and well-stocked libraries that create an inspiring learning environment.

sources.snippet: Construction year: 1974 Architect: Louis I KahnArchitecture style: Modern Architecture. Indian Institute of Management is an iconic institution designed by Louis Kahn, is a m√©lange of Modern Architecture and Indian traditions in design. The architect was approached by the world-renowned Indian architect B.V Doshi to design 60 acres of the institute.
sources.shortName: Ahmedabad City Guide: 8 historical and modern architecture to visit

sources.snippet: Louis Kahn, an architect from AmericaÔøΩs Havard University has designed the structure of Indian Institute of Management (IIM-A-1962). The construction with exposed bricks catches everyoneÔøΩs attention. Gautam Sarabhai has designed the building of NID (1964) and the geodesic dome of Calico MillÔøΩs Retail Shop.
sources.shortName: Modern Architecture - A Complete Ahmedabad City Guide by Dr. Manek Patel

places.name: Indian Institute Of Management‚ÄìAhmedabad (IIM‚ÄìAhmedabad)

reviews.text: It's one of the best business management colleges of India.. one has to be lucky to get admission in this college.. huge campus with the world best library and top-class faculties with depth of knowledge as deep as Indian Ocean. In-house hostel and accommodation facilities for students and alumni of the institute..Popular not with Indians but students all over the world.. this place houses gym, playground, cafe and souvenirs shop..
"One of the most prestigious business institutions in the country. Feeling privileged to have visited this amazing institute.

IIMA offers a comprehensive and enriched campus environment-combining heritage architecture, full-spectrum academic and residential infrastructure, robust wellness and recreational facilities, and a strong focus on sustainability and social responsibility. Whether you're studying, living, or visiting, it's a holistic space designed for rigorous learning and community engagement.

places.address: 2GMM+54C, Sargam Marg, I I M, Vastrapur, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380015, India

places.generalDescription: Bai Harir Vav in Ahmedabad is an ancient underground stepwell dating back to the 15th century. It is named after Dhai Harir, the superintendent of Sultan Mahmud Begada's harem. The stepwell features elaborate carvings, cascading steps, and cool waters. Visitors can admire the intricate motifs and ornate columns as they descend into its depths.

sources.snippet: Dada Harir Vav, another must-visit historical attraction in Ahmedabad, is an intricately-built stepwell. As per the inscription on the stepwell, it was constructed in the year 1485 by Dhai Harir, who served as the Superintendent of the royal harem of Sultan Mahmud Begada. If you walk down the steps of this five-storied well, you will notice the beautiful carvings on its walls.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

places.name: Bai Harir Vav Ahmedabad

reviews.text: Beautiful and historic stepwell with impressive architecture. The intricate carvings showcase amazing craftsmanship. It's a peaceful spot perfect for history lovers.Could use better maintenance in some areas, and the signage is limited, making it a bit confusing to navigate. Facilities like restrooms are minimal.

This ancient wonder was probably built to access underground water table is an understatement. It is no mean achievement to go five to six stories underground and build something like an ornate mall-like structure in an era absolutely devoid of heavy machinery, earth movers and electricity. A treat to the eyes stands here built just purely relying on human ingenuity and hard labour. It truly is one of the architectural wonders and marvels. It is nice to see it's well preserved and also maintained despite the dense population surrounding it. It would be nice if the water in the well is used regularly so that it doesn't become stagnant and murky.

Lovely place in the bustling city of Ahmedabad! It's a place not known by many. And probably that's good because there is little crowd there. But wait, it is crowded by lot of llangurs. Probably the most I have seen at any place. The architecture is beautiful and it has 5 storey to it. We could only go till the 3rd storey beneath the ground.

places.address: Hanumansingh Rd, Haripura, Asarwa, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380016, India

sources.snippet: Also, the creation of Amdavad- ni- gufa, the building of district panchayat, Tagore hall are among many more that set an impressive example.

sources.snippet: The structures of Tagore Hall and Premabhai Hall draw our attention for their unique architectural design. The wall column outside the building appears unique. The institutional architecture of Prathama Blood Centre and Ahmedabad Management Association (AMA-1991) is modern.
sources.shortName: Modern Architecture - A Complete Ahmedabad City Guide by Dr. Manek Patel

places.name: Tagore Hall

Very specious, clean, well organization, sound system is good. Parking  area is big. All system work well. Neat and clean.
Very good hall very good location very huge and perfect for any event I must say ahmedabad is blessed to have such hall. We recently went for ahmedabad Film festival

Also, the contemporary campus designs of MICA, CEPT and Nirma are much talked about. One of the budding architect, Krunal Jain, who recently opted to shift from Indore to Ahmedabad says, ‚ÄúThe very reason of me opting to come to Ahmedabad is because of its richness.

places.address: Navrangpura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380009, India

places.generalDescription: The Jhulta Minar, also known as the Shaking Minaret, is a fascinating architectural wonder located in Ahmedabad. This historical site consists of two three-story minarets connected by a passage. What makes them unique is that when one minaret shakes, the other vibrates as well, despite the passage between them remaining still. The construction of this monument has puzzled architects and engineers for centuries and continues to captivate tourists with its mysterious design.

sources.snippet: Your trip to the historical places in Ahmedabad cannot be deemed complete without a visit to Jhulta Minara or Shaking Minarets, an intriguing architectural wonder. The two minarets once served as the gateway to the 500-plus-years-old Sidi Bashir Mosque. A unique feature of these minarets is that if you shake either one of them by applying a little force, the other one starts vibrating in just a few seconds.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

places.name: Jhulta Minar, Bibiji Masjid

reviews.text: Historical place. Bibi masjid known as Jhoolta minara (shaking Minar) masjid built by king sultan of Gujarat in 1455. Beutiful masjid having unique facility to pray ladies in the masjid. There is a mesenin floored area with separate entry gate for ladies prayer area. This type unique facility is in 5 to 6 Masjids of Ahmedabad. All these masjids were built by the same  family kings of Gujarat.

A true architectural wonder! Jhulta Minara Masjid, also known as the Shaking Minarets, is a fascinating historical site in Ahmedabad. The unique feature of the minarets-where one shakes and the other vibrates-is an incredible mystery of ancient engineering. The intricate carvings and Mughal-era architecture add to its beauty. Though access to the minarets is restricted, the mosque itself is a peaceful and well-maintained place. A must-visit for history and architecture enthusiasts!

Beautiful Mughal Architecture. The carving on the stones depict the quality of artwork, minutely performed on each and every pillar. Historical place connected with Ahmad Shah, the founder of Ahmadabad. Very calm and peaceful place away from city crowd. Must see. Govt needs to preserve this rapidly eroding monuments.

places.address: 5, Julta Minar Rd, Manhar Nagar Society, Rajpur Hirpur, Gomtipur, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380038, India

places.generalDescription: Adalaj Ni Vav, also known as Adalaj Stepwell, is a 520-year-old architectural marvel located in Gujarat's Adalaj. Constructed in 1499 by Queen Rudabai in memory of her late husband, Rana Veer Singh, this step well features a spiral stairway leading down five levels adorned with intricately carved pillars and arches.

sources.snippet: Another one of the historic stepwells in and around Ahmedabad, Adalaj Vav is located in the namesake village on the outskirts of the city. It was constructed by Queen Rudadevi in 1498 to commemorate Rana Veer Singh ‚Äì her husband and is thus also known as Rudabai Vav. The five-storied structure is built using sandstone in the Solanki architectural style, featuring large pillars, stairways, and intricate carvings.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

places.name: Adalaj Ni Vav

reviews.text:
Adalaj Ni Vav is truly an architectural marvel - a beautifully crafted, age-old stepwell that has been remarkably well maintained over the centuries.

It absolutely deserves a place on your international wonders to visit bucket list. The intricate carvings, stunning pillars, and historic charm make it a must-see for anyone who appreciates history, culture, or architecture.

You'll often find artists sketching and painting, inspired by the intricate designs and peaceful atmosphere.

While the site itself is incredible, the state could invest more in improving travel accessibility, making it easier for travelers from around the world to visit and experience this hidden gem.

Heritage structure with stunning architecture
Badly in need of cleaning
The water is covered with moss and algae and lots of plastic bottles thrown around. As Indians, we should take more pride in our culture and country

We recently had the chance to visit Adalaj Vav, and I must say, it was an experience that exceeded expectations. Located just a short drive from Ahmedabad, this place is a true testament to India's rich heritage and architectural brilliance. If you have even the slightest interest in history, architecture, or photography, this is a must-visit destination.

As soon as we arrived, we were struck by the calm ambiance and the ancient charm that surrounds the area. Despite being centuries old, the stepwell is remarkably well-preserved. The detailed carvings on the stone walls, pillars, and ceilings are truly mesmerizing. From floral motifs to mythological scenes and intricate patterns, every inch of the structure tells a story. It's hard to believe such craftsmanship was done by hand so many centuries ago. You can actually spend hours admiring the work and still feel like there's more to discover.

Built in 1499 by Queen Rudabai, the stepwell is not just an architectural wonder but also holds significant cultural and spiritual importance. It was originally built to provide water to the arid region and served as a resting place for travelers. What makes Adalaj Stepwell unique is its five-story depth, and the blend of Hindu and Jain architectural styles, which makes it a rare and visually stunning heritage site.

One of the things that stood out during our visit was how cool it felt inside the well, even when the outside temperature was high. It's no wonder locals used this place as a retreat during hot summers. The stepwell was designed to maintain a lower temperature inside, and it works even today.

places.address: 5H8J+M3R, Adalaj, Gujarat 382421, India

places.generalDescription: Sarkhej Roza is a captivating mosque and tomb complex that beautifully showcases the Indo-Saracenic architectural style, completed in 1451. Nestled amidst a serene landscape featuring a tranquil lake, this historical site reflects the rich Islamic culture intertwined with Persian influences and elements from Hindu and Jain traditions. Often hailed as the Acropolis of Ahmedabad, Sarkhej Roza stands as a testament to the city's heritage during Sultan Mahmud Begada's reign.

sources.snippet: The historical complex of Sarkhej Roza, built at the onset of the Sultanate era, comprises a mosque and several tombs. Though there are several Rozas spread across Gujarat, Sarkhej Roza attracts visitors with its striking architecture, which is a fine blend of Indian and non-Indian styles. Intricate carvings, ornamental motifs, and splendid latticework adorning the complex are some of the factors that make Sarkhej Roza one of the most beautiful historical places to visit in Ahmedabad.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

sources.snippet: Portraying Islamic Architecture, this place has a group of tombs and pillars that make up the beautiful complex of Sarkhej Roza. Built around the artificial body called Sarkhej Lake, it follows the Islamic architecture principles and has become the architectural attraction of the city. It has Hindu motifs and brackets and pillars of Islamic elements.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ahmedabad for the Travelling Architect - RTF
Top 5 Historical Architectural Marvels of Ahmedabad

places.name: Sarkhej Roza

reviews.text: It as a peaceful and serene place, appreciating the intricate details, exquisite craftsmanship, and tranquil surroundings. The site is also noted for its historical significance and the artistry displayed in the latticework and calligraphy.

‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ - A Magnificent Historical Complex with Some Practical Considerations

Sarkhej Roza is truly a hidden gem of Ahmedabad with its breathtaking architecture. The complex houses beautiful tombs of kings and queens, showcasing amazing historical significance. I was particularly impressed by the grand and picturesque lake that enhances the serene atmosphere of this ancient site.

The architecture is fascinating with its unique stylistic elements. The open courtyard provides a wonderful space to appreciate the intricate details of the structure and offers great photo opportunities. The exquisite lattice work and carved pillars throughout the complex are truly mesmerizing, especially when sunlight filters through.

Important note: You must remove your footwear before entering the complex, which can be uncomfortable as the ground gets very hot and dirty. I strongly recommend wearing socks as mentioned in the guidelines. Also, avoid visiting during rainy days as the experience will be compromised, and extremely hot days can make the visit unbearable since you'll be walking barefoot on hot surfaces.

Despite these minor inconveniences, Sarkhej Roza is definitely worth visiting for its historical significance and architectural beauty if you plan your visit during comfortable weather conditions.

Sarkhej Roza is a historically significant tomb complex with stunning Indo-Islamic architecture, but it's sadly not well maintained.

The entrance lacks the presence of a protected heritage site, and the overall upkeep doesn't do justice to its legacy. It deserves better maintenance and stronger promotion to attract the attention it truly merits.

places.address: Post Jeevraj Park, Sarkhej Makarba Rd, Makarba, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380051, India

sources.shortName: Modern Architecture - A Complete Ahmedabad City Guide by Dr. Manek Patel

places.name: Nirma University

reviews.text:
Nirma University is a well-organized and expansive campus in Ahmedabad, known for its strong academic reputation. The infrastructure is modern and well-maintained, offering a conducive learning environment. The greenery around the campus adds a peaceful atmosphere, making it an enjoyable place to study. The faculty is experienced and approachable, and the university offers a diverse range of courses across various disciplines.

However, some areas, like the on-campus facilities and cafeteria, could use more variety and improvement. Overall, it's an excellent institution for higher education, with a focus on both academics and personal growth.

The campus of Nirma University is well designed and well maintained.

Each dept got a separate building within the campus and eventually the entire campus forms the University campus. Good part is that students from different streams can interact and participate in events and competitions across the university campus.

Its located on S.G. Highway which got proximity to ring road, Gandhinagar and the connectivity to Ahmedabad City area.

One concerning point is that the in-campus hostels get full early on, and the parents will have to opt for the PG & privaye hostels outside which are quite expensive.

Nirma University on SG Highway, Ahmedabad, is a premier institution that stands out for its exceptional infrastructure, academic excellence, and holistic development opportunities. Visiting the campus is an inspiring experience, whether you're a student, parent, or visitor.

The sprawling campus is meticulously maintained, offering a perfect blend of modern facilities and natural greenery. The state-of-the-art laboratories, libraries, and classrooms reflect the university's commitment to providing top-tier education. Additionally, the availability of recreational spaces and sports facilities ensures that students have opportunities to balance academics with extracurricular activities.

The faculty at Nirma University are highly qualified and dedicated, creating a nurturing environment that encourages innovation and critical thinking. Their approachable nature and focus on student development are commendable. The university also hosts various workshops, seminars, and events, providing students with exposure to industry trends and real-world applications.

Another standout feature is the university's emphasis on discipline and ethics, fostering a culture of respect and responsibility among students. The placement cell deserves a special mention, as it ensures robust career opportunities by maintaining strong ties with top-tier companies.

Overall, Nirma University is a beacon of quality education in India, offering an enriching experience that shapes future leaders. It's a place that truly lives up to its reputation and deserves a glowing 5-star rating.

Being an architecture student, I get to learn more by exploring and living among the legendary buildings.

places.name: CEPT University

reviews.text:
An extraordinary university with a gorgeous campus and excellent modern architecture, some of it by renowned Indian architect B.V. Doshi.

The architecture also responds to the tropical climate. The sunken, multi-level library is housed in an internal, climate controlled structure encased within a larger, multiple storey external shell entered at ground level that has multi-storey,  internal voids surrounding the perimeter with enormous,  louvered panels to provide protection from wind and rain while allowing cross-ventilation from all four sides.

The place is accessible to differently abled citizens. Good security measures. The library is amazing, but literature's mostly kindred. Friendly and inclusive student body. Wonderful for art exhibits.

CEPT University's architecture embodies its philosophy of embracing innovation while staying rooted in cultural and environmental contexts. The campus design, with its functional elegance and sustainable practices, fosters an atmosphere of learning, collaboration, and creativity. CEPT University's architectural identity stands as a testament to its role as a premier institution for architectural education and as a hub for shaping the future of the built environment.

places.address: Kasturbhai Lalbhai Campus, University Rd, Navrangpura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380009, India

places.generalDescription: Jhulta Minar, also known as the Shaking Minarets, is a fascinating architectural wonder located in Ahmedabad, Gujarat. Situated within the Sidi Bashir Mosque complex, these minarets are renowned for their unique shaking phenomenon. When one minaret is shaken, the other starts shaking on its own despite being connected by intricate arches and corridors. This perplexing optical illusion has puzzled visitors for centuries and remains an unsolved mystery to this day.

sources.snippet: Jhulta Minar or Shaking Minarets can leave the best of designers and engineers intrigued with its mysterious architecture. The unique characteristics of the place garner the attention of all tourists. Nobody could ever unravel the mystery around how the vibration in one minaret causes vibrations in the next minaret, even though the passage between the two remains vibration-free.
sources.shortName: 16 Historical Places In Ahmedabad For Local Heritage and History

sources.snippet: Often termed as ‚ÄòShaking Minarets‚Äô is a must-visit place for architecture history enthusiasts. It will make us rethink in our scientific minds when the shaking of one makes the other vibrate too within seconds. It becomes worth visiting and witnessing this mystery.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ahmedabad for the Travelling Architect - RTF

places.name: Jhulta Minar, Bibiji Masjid

reviews.text: A true architectural wonder! Jhulta Minara Masjid, also known as the Shaking Minarets, is a fascinating historical site in Ahmedabad. The unique feature of the minarets-where one shakes and the other vibrates-is an incredible mystery of ancient engineering. The intricate carvings and Mughal-era architecture add to its beauty. Though access to the minarets is restricted, the mosque itself is a peaceful and well-maintained place. A must-visit for history and architecture enthusiasts!

Amazing piece of historic architecture! The shaking minarets are truly fascinating. A must-see for anyone interested in ancient engineering and mystery. Interesting concept but poorly maintained. You can't experience the shaking anymore due to restricted access. Needs better care and signage.

Historical place. Bibi masjid known as Jhoolta minara (shaking Minar) masjid built by king sultan of Gujarat in 1455. Beutiful masjid having unique facility to pray ladies in the masjid. There is a mesenin floored area with separate entry gate for ladies prayer area. This type unique facility is in 5 to 6 Masjids of Ahmedabad. All these masjids were built by the same  family kings of Gujarat.

places.generalDescription: Amdavad Ni Gufa is a renowned art gallery in the city, known for its contemporary and cavernous design. The space was designed by the celebrated architect Balkrishna V Doshi and features artwork by legendary Indian artist Maqbool Fida Husain. The gallery's unique cave-like structure makes it stand out among modern architecture in India, with interconnected domes supported by tree-like pillars.

sources.snippet: Construction year: 1995 Architect: B V DoshiArchitecture style: Modern Architecture. The Amdavad ni Gufa, earlier known as Husain-Doshi ni Gufa, is an underground art gallery that was designed by the pioneer architect B V Doshi. The art gallery was dedicated to showcasing the works of the well-renowned late master artist Maqbool Fida Hussian.
sources.shortName: Ahmedabad City Guide: 8 historical and modern architecture to visit

sources.snippet: Amdavad-ni-Gufa (1992) is a creation of well known painter M.F. Hussain and architect Padmashri Balkrishna Doshi collaboratively. It is an underground ferrocement structure with optimally structured roof shells in china mosaic protruding over ground.
sources.shortName: Modern Architecture - A Complete Ahmedabad City Guide by Dr. Manek Patel

sources.snippet: Another name as ‚ÄòHussain-Doshi Gufa‚Äô is designed to show how art and architecture go hand in hand. The intimate spaces of the Gufa have the largest painting of Maqbool Fida Hussain and have the experimental use of ferrocement for its structure.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ahmedabad for the Travelling Architect - RTF

places.name: Amdavad Ni Gufa

reviews.text: A unique underground art gallery with a very creative and peaceful vibe. The architecture is unlike anything else dome-shaped, cave-like, and beautifully lit. Showcases modern art in a truly unusual setting. Worth a visit if you're into art, design, or just something different in the city.

The cave is unique! Once you go in you'll understand what the murals and the structures are trying to convey. Well made! There's a nice cafe where like-minded people sit and discuss art. A gallery is there as well with fee entry

The Amdavad ni Gufa was built during my final years at CEPT, a time when it captured the imagination of every student. Its cave-like form was mesmerizing, not just for its concept but also for its unconventional construction techniques, particularly the use of ferrocement.

Colleagues who had worked at B.V. Doshi's office shared fascinating insights-Doshi, the visionary Pritzker Prize-winning architect, would often sketch directly on-site, and the team would build from those sketches. The steps leading to the Gufa's entrance, they say, were first marked directly on the ground, constructed, and only then documented into drawings.

The shimmering china mosaic domes were a source of fascination for students. It was commonly referred to as the "Doshi-Hussain Gufa," though originally named "Hussain-Doshi Gufa" before it was dedicated to the people of Ahmedabad and rechristened "Amdavad ni Gufa."

At the back, a door and pathway evoke images of Indus Valley Civilization structures unearthed at Lothal and Mohenjodaro, with a ramp descending into the earth. The intricate designs on the door grills add to its enigmatic charm.

A building with no defined purpose-simply a place to sit, read, and reflect. M.F. Hussain had painted spontaneous, sketch-like figures on the interior domes, though nothing substantial. Some of his cutout drawings remain, adding to the ambiance. Children are particularly enthralled by the mysterious structure. For years, they were allowed to play atop the domes, but recently, this has been restricted to preserve the aging china mosaic.

A marvel of architecture, the Gufa stands strong-though perhaps in the near future, it may require thoughtful restoration to preserve its legacy.

places.address: 2GPX+GW6, Kasturbhai Lalbhai Campus Opp Gujarat University campus, CEPT campus, Navrangpura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380009, India

places.generalDescription: The Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum, located within the LD Institute of Indology, is a treasure trove of ancient and medieval Indian art and artifacts. Visitors can marvel at Jain, Hindu, and Buddhist deities crafted in marble, bronze, and stone.

sources.snippet: Although the museum itself is not historical, the museum contains many historical items which deeply reflect the culture and traditions of the land. There are sculptures- mostly made from copper and brass, miniature paintings, wood work, idols and figurines, drawings and many other important scrolls and documents. The museum itself is located within the premises of the LD Institute of Indology.
sources.shortName: 12 Magnificent Historical Places In Ahemdabad That You Must Visit

sources.snippet: He designed the new building of museum in 1964 of ÔøΩGandhi Smarak SangrahalayaÔøΩ, keeping in mind GandhijiÔøΩs residence ÔøΩHridaykunjÔøΩ and other buildings. sources.snippet: The Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum (also known as L. D. Museum) is museum of Indian Sculptures, Bronzes, Manuscripts Paintings, Drawings, Miniature Paintings, Wood works, Bead works and coins. (br) The Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum of the Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Bharatiya Sanskriti Vidyamandir is located in the premises of the L.D. Institute of Indology, Ahmedabad.
sources.shortName: 16 Historical Places In Ahmedabad For Local Heritage and History

places.name: Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum

reviews.text:
During 1956, Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Institute of Indology was established with the joint efforts of Shri. Kasturbhai Lalbhai, a wellknown and prominent Ahmedabad based industrialist, and Jain Acharya Muni. Punyavijayji. Muni. Punyavijayji donated his personal collection of illustrated and un-illustrated manuscripts, bronzes and cloth paintings at time at the establishment of Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Indological Institute. With the passage of time the collection grew more and more prominent which created a need for an exclusive display of the artifacts. Thus, in 1984 a new building adjacent to the L.D. Institute of Indology was built by internationally acclaimed architect Shri. Balakrishna Doshi. The L.D. Museum was formally inaugurated by Shri. Brajkumar Nehru, the then Governor of Gujarat in 1985.

Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum is open from 10:30 AM in the morning till 5:30 PM in the evening on all days except for Mondays and public holidays. For group visits, the museum has to be informed earlier and can take a guided tour. There is no entry fee to visit Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum.
This houses a significant collection of Jain art, including sculptures, scrolls, manuscripts, and miniature paintings.¬†Its architecture, designed by renowned architect Balkrishna Doshi, is notable for its integration of modernist and brutalist elements, with a focus on natural light and ventilation.
The Lalbhai Dalpatbhai (LD) Museum in Ahmedabad, India, is a case study in museum design and its connection to the preservation and display of cultural heritage
Overall a very enriching experience.  Must visit.

They allow photography on lower floor which is the department of sculptures. Photography is prohibited on upper floor which is paintings section. The collection is not large but well maintained. Entry is free. They give free pamphlets highlighting the museum collection.

A Hidden Gem of Art & History in Ahmedabad!

The Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum is a must-visit if you're interested in Indian art, sculpture, manuscripts, or architecture. It's located inside the Gujarat University campus and offers a peaceful, well-maintained space with free entry.

What stood out most were the ancient sculptures, beautifully preserved Jain manuscripts, and rare miniature paintings. The coin gallery and wooden artifacts are also fascinating. The place is Quiet and uncrowded. Extremely clean and well-curated. If you are lucky, you might find some peacock ü¶ö.

I was told that there were Free guided tours available (ask at the desk)

No photography in some galleries, so check signs.
Whether you're a history lover or just curious, this museum offers a deep dive into Gujarat's artistic and spiritual traditions in a peaceful setting. Definitely worth a couple of hours!

places.generalDescription: Rani no Hajiro, also known as Mughalai Bibis Tomb, is a historic tomb complex in Ahmedabad that dates back to the time of Ahmed Shah and other Gujarat Sultanate rulers. This elaborate structure is adorned with intricate mother-of-pearl and metal work and serves as the final resting place for the queens of the empire.

sources.snippet: If you walk around the Manek Chowk area, you will come upon a high enclosure with a lofty gateway wherein the graves of Sultan Ahmed Shah‚Äôs consorts lie. Hence, this tomb complex is known as Rani no Hajiro or Mughalai Bibi‚Äôs Tomb, which means the Queen‚Äôs tomb. Unlike the other tomb complexes in the city, this one has the graves placed in an open courtyard.
sources.shortName: 13 Best Historical Places in Ahmedabad: Location & Timings

sources.snippet: ‚ÄòRani no Hajiro‚Äô meaning ‚ÄòQueens Tomb‚Äô holds the graves of the queen consorts of Ahmed Shah. Juxtaposing the chaotic nature of the city, what marks this place is for the calmness it offers. Unlike other tombs, the graves here are not placed in the closed tomb, but in the open courtyard.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Ahmedabad for the Travelling Architect - RTF

places.name: Rani no Hajiro

reviews.text:
I recently visited Rani no Hajiro in Ahmedabad, which is a great place for shopping. You can find beautiful traditional clothes, jewellery, and accessories at very good prices.
After shopping, I went to Manekchowk, which is very famous for street food. I tried Mahalaxmi Bhajipav, sandwich, and the popular gotala dosa. everything was delicious! The place is full of energy at night and perfect for food lovers.

‚ÄúRani no Hajiro: A Hidden Gem in Ahmedabad‚Äù

Rani no Hajiro is a beautiful yet underrated historical site tucked away in the bustling Manek Chowk food area. It's a hidden gem surrounded by local residences and the lively old bazaar, offering a unique blend of history and everyday life.

What Makes It Special:
‚Ä¢	Intricate Architecture: The beautiful windows with intricate carvings and neglected yet charming structures give it a timeless aura. It's a treat for architecture enthusiasts and photographers.
‚Ä¢	Hidden Location: The site is well-hidden and not overly crowded, adding to its charm as a peaceful escape amidst the chaos of Manek Chowk.

Things to Note:
‚Ä¢	Neglect and Maintenance: Unfortunately, the structures are not well-maintained, and the surrounding area can feel a bit neglected.
‚Ä¢	Accessibility: You can't take your car here-it's best to park on the main road and explore the area on foot. Walking through the narrow lanes of the old bazaar is an experience in itself.
‚Ä¢	Ask for Directions: Don't rely solely on Google Maps. It's better to ask locals for directions, as the area can be tricky to navigate.

Tips:
‚Ä¢	Combine your visit with a stroll through the old bazaar and enjoy the food and vibe of Manek Chowk.
‚Ä¢	Be prepared for some walking, and take your time exploring this hidden slice of Ahmedabad's history.

If you're a lover of history and hidden treasures, Rani no Hajiro is worth the visit despite its challenges. It's a glimpse into the city's rich past amidst its thriving present!
Went for random photoshoot but you can buy oxidised jewellery and enjoy street food of Ahmedabad city... heritage buildings and pod culture.

places.name: MICA

reviews.text: Quaint educational campus in Shela village. The flora & fauna on the campus are worth exploring.

MICA is one of the best management colleges in India for marketing, communication, and creativity. It's ranked 32nd in the NIRF Management Rankings 2024.

What sets MICA apart is its unique focus on subjects like Cultural Context of Communication, Imagining India, Strategic Communication not something you find in regular B-schools.

The campus is beautiful, full of greenery, and has a calm vibe that makes it a great place to study and relax. Its an ecosystem to monkeys, peacocks, birds, cats, dogs. Classes are interactive and full of discussions, not just theory.

MICA also has a strong placement record, with top companies coming in for roles in brand management, product management, sales media, strategy and consulting .

If you're looking for a B-school that blends creativity with strategy and offers real-world learning, MICA is a great choice.

reviews.text: Very professional, polite and hospitable team! As patient listeners, both husband wife team appeared to be very knowledgeable. üôÇ

I recently visited Mr. Suthar's Studio for interior design consultation for my 3 BHK apartment. Unfortunately, the experience was underwhelming.

Instead of actively engaging with my project, Mr. Suthar seemed disinterested and suggested I seek services elsewhere. He then proceeded to offer unsolicited advice on validating materials like colors and plywood, which felt inappropriate and condescending.

Furthermore, when I inquired about the estimated cost, he provided a blanket figure of 50L without even reviewing my floor plan.

This lack of due diligence and the subsequent suggestion that I may not be able to afford his services were highly unprofessional and left me feeling undervalued as a client.

Overall, I am extremely disappointed with the interaction and would not recommend Mr. Suthar's Studio to others seeking interior design services.
Architect is stubborn and arrogant. I won't recommend to others. He did good work but doesn't consider our suggestions. Tried to insist his own idea.

places.generalDescription: The Map Store offers a seamless and top-notch experience for those looking to purchase unique and elegant maps. Customers have praised the store's excellent selection, easy ordering process, and exceptional customer service. The wooden world map, in particular, has been highlighted as a true work of art that adds elegance to any space. Additionally, the store is commended for its trustworthy and reliable service, with prompt delivery even for international orders.

places.name: The Map Stores

reviews.text:
I recently purchased the 3D Wooden Map from TheMapStores, and it has truly transformed the look of my living space. The craftsmanship is impeccable ‚Äì every detail on the map is precise and beautifully finished. The wooden pieces are lightweight yet sturdy, making it easy to mount on the wall, and the 3D effect adds a striking depth to the decor.

What I love most is how versatile it is; it works as both a conversation starter and a minimalist wall art piece. Whether you're a travel enthusiast or just looking for unique home decor, this map is a fantastic choice.

Delivery was quick, and the product was securely packaged to ensure no damage during transit. The included instructions made installation a breeze.

Highly recommend this to anyone looking to add a touch of elegance and personality to their home or office. A perfect blend of functionality and aesthetics!

I bought a L size 2D black and blue wooden world map. The installation was very easy if you follow the instructions. The product quality is really good. Very happy with the outcome.

I used an acrylic sheet at the back which will make it hassle free whenever you want to relocate the map.

At the time of my office interior start it was clear that on my main element of office is Map, as we are traveling company, an for this.... map store help us decided the size as per my interior wall. An after we order it was much an above the excpectaion, simply awesome product....i 100% Recomnd this product.

places.generalDescription: Bhadra Fort, a historic fortress constructed in 1411, is situated on the eastern banks of the Sabarmati River. It was built by Sultan Ahmad Shah, the founder of Ahmedabad city. Throughout its history, various rulers gained control over the fort until it was ultimately taken over by the British in 1817 after defeating the Marathas.

sources.snippet: The Bhadra Fort and its neighboring environment is the most scenic part of Ahmedabad. Located in the middle of lush greenery the huge 44 acre Fort got its name from the Bhadrakali Temple that it houses. Ahmedabad has a rich history of its own, lying at the helm of all affairs and intrigues.
sources.shortName: 16 Historical Places In Ahmedabad For Local Heritage and History

places.name: Bhadra Fort

reviews.text:
Bhadra Fort is a historic gem located in the heart of old Ahmedabad, right next to the bustling Teen Darwaza Market. Built in 1411 by Sultan Ahmad Shah I, the founder of Ahmedabad, the fort once served as the royal residence of the Gujarat Sultanate.

We visited the fort during our family trip to Ahmedabad. After walking past the vibrant lanes near Lal Darwaza Market, filled with roadside vendors selling clothes, toys, flowers, and fresh produce, we reached the fort's entrance. It's just a short walk from the iconic Sidi Saiyyed Mosque.

Entry is free, and though the place wasn't crowded inside, security allowed us to walk through the main gate. The fort has eight massive gates, and we could still see the strong outer walls and the old British-era clock tower attached to one of the walls. On the right side of the main path, the Bhadra Kali temple stands - historically preserved since the time of the Sultan. Though the inner door was closed, the temple is said to have a lamp that has been burning continuously for over 600 years.

There's also a small mosque inside, though its entrance was locked during our visit. The front area of the fort is currently used by some government offices.

Overall, Bhadra Fort offers a great glimpse into Ahmedabad's medieval past. A calm and historical site amidst the chaos of the old city - definitely worth a quick visit if you're exploring the nearby markets or historical spots.

A beautiful fort but we went here in Dec 2024 but they have shut the fort for tourist to go up and see. The base of the fort is open. The architecture is beautiful and the temple at the base, Bhadrakali temple is most famous and visited
Every Sunday there is local market in this area and hence the shopping experience here is amazing for great product's in very economical prices

"Underwhelming Experience at Bhadra Fort"

Bhadra Fort is disappointing as a tourist spot. The fort itself is just a massive entrance with nothing much to explore inside. However, the area outside the fort is bustling with a street shopping market, mainly catering to women. The market is huge but has its downsides.

The worst part is the pricing-there's no scope for bargaining, and the prices are unreasonably high. Considering the rates, it's better to invest in branded items instead.

Parking is another major issue. Cars have no chance here, and even for bikes, managing to find a spot is a struggle.

Overall, it's not worth visiting unless you're specifically interested in exploring the market.

places.generalDescription: Sanskar Kendra, a striking modernist edifice designed by Le Corbusier, is home to museums dedicated to Ahmedabad's history and kites. The museum showcases the city's rich history, art, and culture dating back to the 11th century. Visitors can explore sections on art history, India's independence struggle, and the city's religious communities. Additionally, it houses the world's tallest incense stick at 4.5 meters long.

sources.snippet: Whether it‚Äôs the Gandhi Smarak Sangrahalaya designed by Charles Correa or the Sanskarkendra and Ahmedabad Textile Mills Association (ATMA) building of Le Corbusier, the old form of architecture truly blends with the modern one here. It is after independence that the artists and architects grappled with the need of finding Indianness in their work. A legend himself, B.
sources.shortName: Creative tale of Amdavad‚Äôs iconic buildings | Ahmedabad News

sources.snippet: Construction year: 1954 Architect: Le CorbusierArchitecture style: Modern Architecture. The Sanskar Kendra is a museum dedicated to the art, culture, architecture, and history of the city designed by the Swiss-French architect Le Corbusier. The Sanskar Kendra City Museum was originally designed to be a part of Ahmedabad‚Äôs Cultural Center complex; eventually, only the museum was constructed.
sources.shortName: Ahmedabad City Guide: 8 historical and modern architecture to visit

places.name: Sanskar Kendra

reviews.text:
Real Beautiful building which is deteriorating with time and officials are doing nothing about it...It comes under Heritage sites of India but the maintenance is very poor...The artefacts are not cleaned for a long time..
It is a must visit place for Architectural Lovers as it is the work of Le Corbusier.
This Building resembles 90% of the building of Chandigarh which are shopping complexes.

Here is a museum which is less known. Entry is free. Indias only kite museum is also placed here.
Good presentation of various things including textile and artifacts etc. You will need 1 to 2 hours. Piblic utilities are available...
One time must visit.

Taking your mobile inside Sanskar Kendra is allowed but you can't take snapshots there. You are being watched by a CCTV CAMERA & after some time they will request you to delete the snaps you have taken. Monday closed. However there is a lot of information about Gujarat , Bollywood history & kite culture etc.
